column6: definition
The character who is the direct cause of all of the bad happenings in a story.
A character who is so completely obnoxious that it is unbelievable anyone would willingly interact with them.
A villain whose politeness is an act that only serves to enhance their evil.
A type of character (usually a villain) who tends to treat friends and enemies alike with equal disdain.

This includes parents who are emotionally, verbally, physically, or mentally abusive, or who neglectfully allow their children to be abused 
by others if they don't abuse the child themselves
People that do hurt children, sometimes even kill them.
An Action Girl is a female badass who is tough and kicks butt.

Authirity that is open to heros' inasane ideas.  Often, they'll ask for proof and facts rather than follow baseless accusations, but even then, 
they'll usually humor the heroes and go check out their theories.

Paternal instinct can transform a Bumbling Dad into an Action Dad. If someone threatens his kids they will soon wish 
they'd never come within a mile of them.
A character prone to gnomic, sarcastic, sometimes bitter, occasionally whimsical asides.
A character \ good or evil, male or female, young or old \ who never gives up. Ever. No matter what.

When there is a group of characters who are all just totally weird, either in general or in a particular scenario, the Only Sane Man is the only 
one who, well, isn't.
An antihero is a protagonist who has the opposite of most of the traditional attributes of a hero.
When the victim is a bad guy.

column5: Jerk with a Heart of Gold
column6: A person you would expect to be a big Jerkass has some redeeming qualities behind their tough demeanor.
Keep a villain safely on the "still sympathetic" side of the Moral Event Horizon; give him something that he simply will not do.

Villains that are not too bad. There is absolutely nothing separating them from being normal, polite people except for the fact that they want 
to take over the world.
People who are so stupid that they simply do not deserve to survive.
The character who is always the butt of the demeaning joke or the "put them through hell" plotline.
An "ax-crazy" character is someone who is psychologically unstable and presents a clear and immediate danger to others.

An adorkable character might be socially inept, shy or clumsy. However, rather than making them an outcast, these quirks give the character 
an endearing vulnerability.
Some characters always get enraged when given a certain, minor trigger.

A female character who provides a significant amount of Fanservice (generally for males), ranging from simple revealing of cleavage, midriff, 
shoulders or legs, to shots of her curves, hips or derriere (even when covered).
This person likes their liquor, and in large amounts.
The father of a character or characters is missing or absent.
A guy (good or evil) has no problems with violence against women.
The moment at which a character realizes that something really, REALLY bad is about to happen.
Whatever the reason, a character may be driven to commit suicide.
Things that mature, well-adjusted adults generally are concerned about, as opposed to supernatural fears.

When one character in a pair (who'd otherwise be different and/or unrelated) discovers that they actually have some things in common, more 
than the other character would want to believe.

A stunning revelation or horrible event affects a character or someone they care deeply about, leaving them shocked to the point of mentally
 shutting down for a while.

The moment when a character realizes that something awful has happened, or notices that something awful is about to happen, and screams 
"NOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!"

When the creator of a work takes advantage of our Primal Fear of having something utterly horrible happen to our eyes, usually involving the 
invasion of the eye sockets by a foreign body.
Blood or brains are seen splattering against a wall and the rest is left to the imagination.
When someone gets stabbed in a really extreme way..
When someone is going to get his head chopped off.
Villains exit the film by falling off or out of things.
Cheating on your partner.
One character delivers a speech to another character on all the reasons why that other character sucks or is a horrible person.

Tempting Fate is when a character says something that dares the universe into making things miserable for them, and the universe takes them up 
on the challenge.
the situation where a person let the opponent know that if they so much as sneeze on someone you protect, it will cost them a limb.

The character has got to be pretty impressive to be able to make this kind of boast convincingly, though sometimes a weaker character will 
bluff like this.
Groin attack

The Roaring Rampage of Revenge differs from the standard Revenge plot in that our hero dispenses with the Machiavellian plotting that would 
define a classic revenge tale and goes straight for the bloodshed.
Any time the heroes/anti heroes get to save the day in a big, awesome manner.
A character saves another/others from harm and is killed, crippled, or maimed as a result.
Screw you guys, I'm going home.

When a character does something evil for no apparent gain, because the author wants to demonstrate that he's not a nice guy and shift 
audience sympathy away from him.
Show the nasty old crank petting a dog, and you show the audience, aw shucks, they're not that bad of a person after all.
The tendency of relatively calm and composed villains to lose their cool over the course of the story.
When a character suddenly swears in an uncharacteristically strong manner, or when a swear is unexpectedly used in a work with mild language.
Lots of swearing occur.
When a jerkass is right.
A moment where a character's stupidity fuels an episode, or a small plot line.
A plan that revolves entirely around people doing exactly what you'd expect them to do.

Whenever someone in film or on TV reports a murder, or a monster, or a stalker or whatever, the police come as close to ignoring them 
as procedure will allow.
There is almost always someone, person or monster, The Hero has to get past to get at the Big Bad.
The hero's ride has to be just as unique and awesome as the hero is. Enter a Cool Car!
This is any form of horror or squickiness involving body parts, parasitism, disfigurement, mutation, or unsettling bodily configuration.
A character is revealed as another character's father, a god, or secret suitor or arch nemesis in disguise.
A fight that's extremely one-sided, where one side just absolutely trashes the other with little-to-no effort
Sometimes people just won't believe you even though you are telling the truth, because the truth sounds insane.
A glaringly obvious lie.
A Crapsack World is a horrible setting of the world where it's dark and hopeless
A character completely misses a really obvious point for comic effect.
The use of sex or sexualized situations to reward or entice viewers.

Fan Disservice looks like regular garden variety Fanservice, except that the creators intentionally use the circumstances around it to make the 
scene outright creepy or disgusting.
When two seemingly unrelated jokes work together to create a comedic effect.
A type of gag in which a character's actions or words contradict each other and this is Played for Laughs.

column5: Does This Remind You of Anything?
column6: Any situation which is made, sometimes for comic effect, sometimes for dramatic effect, to look like another situation.

A sub-genre of comedy and satire where topics and events that are usually treated seriously are treated in a satirical manner, while still being 
portrayed as the negative events that they are.
The intended meaning is an inversion of the plain meaning.
When the exact wording of a rule, promise, prophecy, etc. matters more than the spirit of the wording, it's an Exact Words situation.
The writers put in a joke (almost always a pun), but never make or put in a Punch Line or explicit statement, hiding it in the set up of the joke.

When victory came at a harsh price, when, for whatever reason, the heroes cannot fully enjoy the reward of their actions, when some 
irrevocable loss has happened during the course of the events, and nothing will ever be the same again.

The character has done a number of things that deserve a karmic comeuppance, most importantly things that caused harm to the innocent. But 
when the time comes for the hammer to fall, that's not what happens. At least, not on them. They don\t get what they deserve.
A finale to a movie that ends things in a way that varies from sad to tragic.
If you mistreat the people and things around you, karma will strike you down.

A cast of characters in a story go through a lot more hardship, anguish and grief than is really necessary. In the end, however, you see them get 
their happily-ever-after.
When the villain dies in a manner that is completely their own fault. Or, at least, obviously not the hero's.
The hero has accomplished their goal, but it turns out that by the very act of success, they've unwittingly made things worse.

column5: My God, What Have I Done?
column6:
Well-intentioned but misguided character (very likely a Tragic Hero, a Tragic Villain or Anti-Villain) comes to realize that his actions have
 caused incredible damage, physical pain, emotional pain, or even loss of life.
When characters In-Universe call out one of the heroes for doing something clearly unheroic, if not outright heinous.

The Protagonist is about to face utter defeat. Suddenly, he finds a glimmer of hope what have you only to be crushed cruelly by the bad guys 
returning in force.
When a bad guy turns good.
A charcter who is transformed into someone stronger and tougher that the viewer almost can't recognize him.
An insignificant object that later turns out to be important.
A clue or allusion embedded in the narrative that predicts some later event or revelation.
Training in any kind of skill, ability, or knowledge that will likely later come in handy.
Any character who is innocuously and unimportantly introduced to the viewer, but who later proves to be important by the end of the episode.
A clue that leads in the wrong direction.
When a character repeats a comment they received in a different situation, giving it a flipped or surprising new meaning.
The villain's own weapon or malicious plan is the cause of their downfall and/or death.
It occurs when characters, in their usual way, say things to one another, and repeat it later on to give extra meaning.
The villain had an abusive and particularly violent childhood (such as Abusive Parents, being bullied by peers, etc.), making them insane and warping their perception on the universe
